title: A 12 Week, Multicenter, Open Label Evaluation of Caregiver Preference, Safety and Tolerability of Exelon® Patch (Rivastigmine Transdermal) in Patients With Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: This study is designed to evaluate caregiver preference for Exelon® patch (target patch size 10 cm²) treatment in patients with Alzheimer's disease (MMSE 10-26) who were under cholinesterase inhibitor treatment and experienced adverse event/s in a community setting.
explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests Exelon® patch (rivastigmine transdermal). Rivastigmine is a centrally-acting acetylcholinesterase (cholinesterase) inhibitor that increases cholinergic neurotransmission and is used to improve cognitive symptoms in Alzheimer’s disease — a symptomatic (cognitive-enhancing) treatment rather than a biologic or a disease-modifying agent. citeturn0search3turn0search7

Act (key extracted details and sources): The intervention named in the protocol is Exelon® patch (rivastigmine transdermal; target patch size 10 cm²) given to patients with AD (MMSE 10–26) in an open-label caregiver-preference, safety and tolerability study — i.e., a trial of a small-molecule transdermal cholinesterase inhibitor focusing on symptomatic benefit and tolerability. Regulatory/label and product information for Exelon® Patch support this description. citeturn0search8turn0search0

Act: Key extracted details — intervention: Exelon® patch (rivastigmine transdermal, target/maintenance dose 9.5 mg/24 h delivered from a 10 cm² patch in many studies); indication: symptomatic treatment of mild–moderate (and in some approvals, severe) Alzheimer’s dementia; mechanism: reversible inhibition of acetylcholinesterase (and butyrylcholinesterase) leading to increased acetylcholine. These details support classification under neurotransmitter modulation. citeturn0search3turn0search4turn0search8
